197C.description: Experience "behind-the-scenes" at the Pacific Film Archive! Interns will learn about film curating through creating a program of works by UC Berkeley students to present at PFA the following spring semester. Students will solicit films and videos, preview them, and make a final selection as a group. Students will write short analyses of local film exhibition programs and will do projects related to PFA's ongoing exhibition program.
197C.title: Film Curating Internship

128.description: A survey of the history, theory, and practice of the documentary film (including video). How have the forms and ethics of the documentary changed since the beginning of cinema? A range of practices and strategies will be covered: cinema verite, direct cinema, narrational documentary, autobiography, investigative documentary, and recent fictional styles that combine the essayistic with the observational. The course moves between classic works of the genre as well as highly experimental works that critique traditional approaches. Throughout, the emphasis will be on the formal analysis of the films focusing on their narrative structures and the ways in which they make meaning.
128.title: Documentary

298.description: Designed to allow students to do research in areas not covered by other courses. Requires regular discussions with the instructor and a final written report.
298.title: Special Study

25B.description: The sound era from World War II to present time.
25B.title: The History of Film

25A.description: From the beginnings through the conversion to sound up until World War II era. In addition to the development of the silent film, the course will conclude with an examination of the technology of sound conversion and examples of early sound experiments.
25A.title: The History of Film

240.description: Selected topics in the study of film.
240.title: Graduate Topics in Film

C187.description: This advanced studio course is designed for students who have mastered basic skills and concepts involved in digital video production and are interested in further investigating critical, theoretical, and creative research topics in digital video production.
C187.title: Advanced Digital Video

201.description: The theoretical and methodological issues raised by the recent practice of film history are the focus of this seminar. Intended primarily for first-year film studies graduate students and other students interested in starting work on film history, the seminar provides both a theoretical overview of film historiography and an introduction to the practice of historically oriented film research. The first part of the course uses both overtly historiographic readings and film history examples to raise historical questions of technology, institution-formation, exhibition, cultural history, and spectatorship.
201.title: Graduate Film Historiography

197B.description: The supervised field program may include experience in a broad range of pre- and post-production film and video production related activities. The student will develop the field experience and its relationship to academic training with a member of the faculty on the Film Advisory Committee. Faculty sponsor and student will establish individual meeting times and academic requirements for acceptable completion of the course. Commitment to at least nine hours of field work per week.
197B.title: Field Studies for Majors

R1B.description: Intensive argumentative writing stimulated through selected readings, films, and class discussion. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition requirement.
R1B.title: The Craft of Writing - Film Focus

187.description: This course investigates special topics in, and special technologies of, media production: e.g., experimental film, documentary film, digital special effects, etc. This is a hands-on studio course designed for students who have mastered the basics of media production and are ready to pursue more specialized film or video production.
187.title: Special Topics in Media Production

H195.description: Students in the honors program are to take H195 for a letter grade to complete a senior honors thesis. Although the production of a film may be part of the preparation of the thesis and the film submitted as a documentation or example, it is expected that the thesis will be a substantial piece of writing of film criticism or film history.
H195.title: Film Honors Thesis

299.description: Open to graduate students who have passed their Ph.D. qualifying examinations.
299.title: Directed Research

20.description: This course is intended to introduce undergraduates to the study of a range of media, including photography, film, television, video, and print and digital media. The course will focus on questions of medium "specificity" or the key technological/material, formal and aesthetic features of different media and modes of address and representation that define them. Also considered is the relationship of individual media to time and space, how individual media construct their audiences or spectators, and the kinds of looking or viewing they enable or encourage. The course will discuss the ideological effects of various media, particularly around questions of racial and sexual difference, national identity, capitalism, and power.
20.title: Film and Media Cultures

180.description: The course explores the art and craft of writing a feature-length, narrative screenplay. Participants present three story ideas to the class, develop one concept into a detailed treatment, and write the first act of the script in professional screenplay form. The focus is on rewriting, with regular presentations of outlines and scripts to fellow writers. The emphasis is on story structure, character development, and screenplay form.
180.title: Introduction to Screenwriting

160.description: This course will focus on the cinema of a particular nation or region.
160.title: National Cinema

R1A.description: Rhetorical approach to reading and writing argumentative discourse with a film focus. Close reading of selected texts; written themes developed from class discussion and analysis of rhetorical strategies. Satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement.
R1A.title: The Craft of Writing - Film Focus

198.description: Group studies of selected topics which vary from year to year. Field shall not coincide with that of any regular course and shall be specific enough to allow students to write an essay based on the study.
198.title: Directed Group Study

199.description: Reading and conference with the instructor in a field that shall not coincide with that of any regular course and shall be specific enough to enable the student to write an essay based upon his/her study.
199.title: Supervised Independent Study for Advanced Undergraduates

197D.description: Interning at <Film Quarterly.> Interns will gain experience in the editorial process. This internship will help the student refine critical skills, develop editorial skills, and experience working on a film journal.
197D.title: Field Study at <Film Quarterly>

140.description: Selected topics in the study of film.
140.title: Special Topics in Film

108.description: The study of films as categorized either by industry-identified genres (westerns, horror films, musicals, film noir, etc.) or broader interpretive modes (melodrama, realism, fantasy, etc.).
108.title: Special Topics in Film Genre

98.description: Supervised research by lower division students.
98.title: Directed Group Study

151.description: The study of films from the perspective of directorial style, theme, or filmmaking career.
151.title: Auteur Theory
